clinical_study.brief_title: A Dose-response of the Effects of Exendin-9,39 on GI Symptoms and Food Intake
clinical_study.official_title: A Dose-response Study of the Effects of Exendin-9,39 on Gastrointestinal Symptoms and Food Intake.

collaborator.agency: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK)

oversight_info.authority: United States: Food and Drug Administration

brief_summary.textblock: Exendin-(9,39) has been shown to have effects on beta-cell function, and after gastric bypass, to accelerate gastrointestinal transit. - infused at rates of 300pmol/kg/min. Given that gastrointestinal transit is typically delayed by Glucagon-Like Peptide-1 (GLP-1) and also that this hormone causes decreased food intake through increased satiation, it is reasonable to expect an effect of Exendin-9,39 on appetite. This may help explain the effects of gastric bypass on food intake. To examine the effect of Exendin on food intake we propose a dose-response study to determine whether the compound has effects in a dose-dependent fashion. We will examine the presence of gastrointestinal symptoms as well as food intake in the immediate aftermath of a test meal and the subsequent hours.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Pharmacokinetics/Dynamics Study, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Basic Science

primary_outcome.measure: Calories consumed during buffet meal test
primary_outcome.description: The calories consumed during buffet meal test at the end of each study test will help determine the effect of GLP-1 receptor blockade with Exendin-9,39 on food intake.

intervention.description: use Exendin-9,39 @ 750pmol/kg/min and Exendin-9,39 @ 300pmol/kg/min to block endogenous GLP-1 in humans after gastric bypass and determine contribution of GLP to satiety after meal ingestion

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Subjects who have undergone Roux en-Y Gastric Bypass at least 6 months prior to enrollment in the study.
- Subjects without active systemic illness.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Subjects <20 years of age will not be studied to minimize the possibility of type 1 diabetes.
- Subjects >70 years of age will not be studied to minimize the potential confounding effects of age on glucose tolerance.
